What is tax return?
When user files his income tax and submit details to Income Tax Department then he should know that his return is valid so that he can claim that he has filed tax.

Categories of Income Tax returns

  1. Normal return u/s 139(1) : Returns filed within the return filing due date, that is 31 July (for non audit assessees) or 30 September (for assessee or their firms liable for audit) of concerned assessment year.
  2. Belated return : In case of failure to file the return on or before the due date, belated return can be filed before the expiry of one year from the end of the relevant assessment year.
  3. Revised return : In case of any omission or any wrong statement mentioned in the normal return can be revised at any time before the expiry of one year from the end of the relevant assessment year.
  4. Defective return : Assessing Officer considers that the return is defective, he may intimate the defect. One has to rectify the defect within a period of fifteen days from the date of such intimation. If the assessee wants more time, he can file an application to the A O and a further 15 days can be granted at the instance of the A O.
  5. Returns in response to notices : Assessing officer in the process of making assessment, may serve a notice under various sections like 142(1), 148(1), 153A(a) or 153C. Returns are required to be furnished within the date specified on the respective notices.

What is ITR-V receipt ?
When you file income tax return without digital signature, on successful online transmission, the system generates an acknowledgement in Form ITR V as specified in rule 12 of the Income Tax Rules, 1961. The Form ITR V shall also contain the e-filing acknowledgement number of the Income tax return and the date of such online transmission as an evidence of e-filing of the income tax return.

What is e-File confirmation?
When you file income tax return electronically with digital signature, and acknowledgment (ITR V) in a specified format has been generated by the server after successful transmission. The ITR V shall contain the e-filing acknowledgement number and date of such filing as an evidence of income tax filing.

What should do after getting confirmation?
A copy of the ITR V can be downloaded and taking printout, it shall be physically verified before putting his signature and after that forward the same CPC, Bangalore office by ordinary post and within the period or extended period specified by the Commissioner. Address to which ITR V has to be sent :
Income Tax Department CPC, Post Bag No. 1, Electronic City Office,
Bengaluru – 560100, Karnataka, India

Why is necessary to receive it?
ITR-V is an evidence of filing income tax with respect to Assessment Year.

What is digital signature?
A digital signature is an electronic signature that can be used to authenticate the identity of the sender of a message or the signer of a document, and possibly to ensure that the original content of the message or document that has been sent is unchanged.
It gives a recipient reason to believe that the message was created by a known sender, such that the sender cannot deny having sent the message (authentication and non-repudiation) and that the message was not altered in transit (integrity).

In India, Digital Signatures are issued by a licensed certifying authority and the Information Technology Act 2000 grants it the same status as a physical signature. Digital Signatures are usually used at the time of statutory and other filings like Income Tax Returns which have to be mandatory signed at the time of submission.

How is it useful for secure e-filing your income tax?

  1. It can not be forged and it asserts that a named person wrote or otherwise agreed to the document to which the signature is attached.
  2. The recipient of a digitally signed message can verify that the message originated from the person whose signature is attached to the document and that the message has not been altered either intentionally or accidentally since it was signed.
  3. The signer of a document cannot later disown it by claiming that the signature was forged. In other words digital signatures enable the â€œauthenticationâ€ and â€œnon-repudiationâ€ of electronic messages assuring the recipient of the electronic message of both the identity of the sender and the integrity of the message.

Registering Digital Signature Certificate on Income Tax Website

  1. Login with your User-id and Password on the Income Tax efiling website i.e. www.incometaxindiaefiling.gov.in
  2. Under the tab â€“ My Account click Digital Signature
  3. Select the appropriate type of DSC (.pfx or USB token) and then click on â€œSelect your .pfx file certificate)

Digital Certificate Verification
In case the Income Tax Assessee is an Individual/ HUF â€“ the email id as registered in his Digital Certificate shall match the email id as per his registered profile in the e-filing website. In case of non-individuals like Firms, Companies etc., the person in holding the Digital Certificate shall either be the Director/Partner in the Key Person schedule of the Firm/Company.

Uploading Income Tax Return Online

  1. Prepare your Income Tax Return and Generate the XML File and save it on your computer
  2. Login to your account on https://incometaxindiaefiling.gov.in/portal/login.do by submitting your user-id and password
  3. Click Submit Return and then select the assessment year

After selecting the Income Tax Form Name, select the type of Digital Signature and then upload your Income Tax Return using the Digital Signature Certificate.

What is ITR forms?
ITRÂ  form stands for Income Tax Return form used by Indian Resident ,Non Residents and Not Ordinary Resident to file their Tax Returns under Income Tax Act, 1961, and the Income Tax Rules, 1962, require citizens to file their tax returns with the Income Tax Department at the end of every financial year.

Classification Of ITR forms
ITR forms are classified on the basis of sources of income of individual. They are categories as

ITR 1
Who can file it?
This Return Form is to be used by an individual whose total income for the assessment year includes:-

  • Income from Salary/ Pension; or
  • Income from One House Property (excluding cases where loss is brought forward from previous years); or
  • Income from Other Sources (excluding Winning from Lottery and Income from Race Horses).In case where the income of another person like spouse, minor child, etc. is to be clubbed with the income of the assessee, this Return Form can be used only if the income being clubbed falls into the above income categories.

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot not be used if

  • Income from Multiple House Property.; or
  • Income under the head Capital Gains Eg. Short-term Capital gains or Long-term Capital Gains from sale of house, plot, shares etc; or
  • Income from Other Sources including winning from lottery and Income from Race Horses; or
  • Income from Agriculture/Exempt income in excess of Rs. 5000; or
  • Resident having any asset (including financial interest in any entity) located outside India or signing authority in any account located outside India.; or
  • Claiming relief of tax under sections 90, 90A or 91; or
  • Income from Speculative Business and Other Special Income; or
  • Income from Profession or Income from agency business or income in the nature of commission for brokerage.

In a case where the income of another person like spouse, minor child, etc. is to be clubbed with the income of the assessee, this Return Form can be used where such income falls in any of the above categories.

ITR 2

  1. Who can file it?
    This Return Form is to be used by an individual whose total income for the assessment year includes:-

    • Income from Salary/ Pension; or
    • Income from House Property; or
    • Income from Capital Gains; or
    • Income from Other Sources (including Winning from Lottery and Income from Race Horses).

    Further, in a case where the income of another person like spouse, minor child, etc. is to be clubbed with the income of the assessee, this Return Form can be used where such income falls in any of the above categories.

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot not be used by an individual whose total income for the assessment year 2012-13 includes Income from Business or Profession.

ITR 3
Who can file it?
This Return is to be used, who is partner in a Firm and where income chargeable include any income except the income by way of any interest, salary, bonus, commission or remuneration, by whatever name called, due to, or received by him from such firm. and has only exempt income by way of share in the profit of the firm, he shall use this form only and not Form ITR-2.

  • Income from Salary / Pension; or
  • Income from Multiple House Property.; or
  • Income under the head Capital Gains Eg.Short-term Capital gains or Long-term Capital Gains from sale of house, plot, shares etc;or
  • Income from Other Sources including winning from lottery and Income from Race Horses; or
  • Income from agriculture/Exempt income in excess of Rs. 5000; or
  • Details of foreign assets; or
  • Claiming relief of tax under sections 90, 90A or 91.

Who can not file it?
This Return Form should not be used by an individual whose total income for the assessment year 2013-14 includes Income from Business or Profession under any proprietorship.

ITR 4
Who can file it?

  • Income from Salary / Pension; or
  • Income & Losses from House Property; or
  • Capital Gains/Loss on sale of investments/ property; or
  • Share of profit of partner from a Partnership Firm; or
  • Income from Other Sources (including winnings from lottery and race horses); or
  • Details of Foreign Assets; or
  • Claiming relief of tax under sections 90, 90A or 91; or
  • Income from Proprietary Business/ Profession.

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot be used if Income comes from Presumptive Business.

ITR 4S
Who can file it?
For Individuals/HUFs who has

  • Income from Presumptive Business; or
  • Income from Salary Pension; or
  • Income from One House Property (Excluding cases where loss is brought forward from previous years); or
  • Income from Other Sources (Excluding winning from lottery and Income from Race Horses).

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot be used if

  • Income is from more than One House Property; or
  • Income from winnings from Lottery and Race Horses; or
  • Income under the head Capital Gains Eg. Short-term Capital gains or Long-term Capital Gains from sale of house, plot, shares etc; or
  • Â Income from Agriculture/Exempt Income in excess of Rs. 5000; or
  • Income from Speculative Business and Other Special Income; or
  • Income from Profession or Income from agency business or income in the nature of commission for brokerage; or
  • Details of foreign assets; or
  • Persons claiming relief of foreign tax paid under sections 90, 90A or 91.

ITR 5
Who can file it?
Firm, LLPs, AOP, BOI, Artificial Juridical Person referred to in section 2(31) (vii) Cooperative society and Local Authority.
Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot not be used by an Individual, HUF, A person who is required to file the return of income under

  • section 139(4A)- Income of Charitable Trust and Institutions; or
  • section 139(4B)- Income of Political Party; or
  • section 139(4C)- Income of certain associations and institutions; or
  • section 139(4D)- Income of University, College or Other Institutions.

ITR 6
Who can file it?
This Form can be used by Companies including:

  • Domestic Company; or
  • Foreign Companies; or
  • Companies in which the public are substantially interested; or
  • Industrial Company

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot not be used by an Individual, HUF and by a Company claiming exemption under section 11. (Charitable Trust).

ITR 7
Who can file it?
This Form can be used by persons including companies who are required to furnish return under; or

  • section 139(4A)- Income of charitable trust and institutions; or
  • section 139(4B)- Income of political party; or
  • section 139(4C)- Income of certain associations and institutions; or
  • section 139(4D)- Income of university, college or other institution.

Who can not file it?
This Return Form cannot not be used by an Individual, HUF and by a Company claiming exemption under section 11. (Charitable Trust)

What is Advance Tax ?
When the assesseeâ€™s total tax liability after TDS is more than Rs. 10,000, then the Provision of advance tax is applicable and tax is paid in the Previous Year itself. However in case of senior citizen who is not carrying on any business or profession, he does not have to pay any advance tax.

Which ITR(s) allows to file it ?

  1. ITR 1
  2. ITR 2
  3. ITR 3
  4. ITR 4
  5. ITR 4S

Due date to pay the tax and rates ?
Non Corporate Assessees

  • On or before 15th September : Not less than 30% of the Tax Payable
  • On or before 15th December Â : Â Not less than 60% of the Tax Payable
  • Â On or before 15th March Â  Â  Â  Â  : Not less than 100% of the Tax Payable

For Corporate Assessee

  • On or before 15 June Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  – not less than 15% of tax payable
  • On or before 15 September Â - not less than 30% of tax payable
  • On or before 15 December Â  – not less than 60% of tax payable
  • On or before 15 March Â  Â  Â  Â  Â - not less than 100% of tax payable

How to pay the tax ?

  • Select Challan No. /ITNS 280 and opt for (0021) Income-tax (Other than Companies)
  • Enter your Pan No., Select Assessment Year (i.e. 2013-14), fill your Address, Mobile No., e-Mail ID, Select type of Payment (i.e. Advance Tax (100))
  • Select your Bank, pay your advance tax liability.
  • After successful payment of tax, keep a copy of the challan for future reference.

What are the penalties on non-payment of Advance Tax ?
If you fail to pay advance tax by due date you can pay the advance tax which you have not paid on the next due date, but you will have to pay interest at the rate of 1 percent for three months.

In case you fail to pay advance tax during the year, for every month or part of delay you have to pay 1 percent interest.

What is employment?
Employment is a relationship between two parties, usually based on a contract, one being the employer and the other being the employee.

Categories of employment
It is divided in four categories in terms of income source with respect to Income Tax filing liability as

  1. Government Category : It will include Public enterprises incorporated under Indian Companies Act 1956 and owned or managed by Central Government / State Governments. For Example : Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Defense etc.
  2. Public Sector Union (P.S.U.) Category : It will include organization which are government owned Corporation (with 51%) which are not privatized and owned by Central Government and State Government.For Example : SBI, ONGC etc.
  3. Other Category : It includes all organization which are not listed under categories of Govt and PSU.
  4. Not Applicable (N.A.) Category : Assessee is not under any employment contract Â (i.e. No Employee and Employer relation exist).

What is Form 16/ Salary Income?

Form 16 represents salary income with TDS detailsÂ  issued by an employer deducting the TDS while making payments to an employee.

As per Income Tax Act, every employer at a time of payment of Salaries shall deduct at the average rate of income tax computed on the basis of Income Tax slab rates in the force for that financial year in which the payments is made on the estimated income of the assesses.

Applies To

  1. ITR 1
  2. ITR 2
  3. ITR 3
  4. ITR 4
  5. ITR 4S

Components of Form 16 are as

  1. Name and PAN of employee.
  2. Name, PAN and TAN of employer
  3. Acknowledgment number of TDS payment deposited with Indian Government
  4. Detailed Salary particulars like House rent allowance, Leave travel allowance, Leave encashment, Pension, Deductions.
  5. Total income and total tax on Salaries thereon
  6. Educational Cess and Surcharge if any
  7. Tax deducted under section 192(1A)
  8. Balance tax payable/tax refundable

This TDS Certificate also contains a declaration at the end that the person deducting the tax has deposited the same with the Central Govt.

Benefits of Form 16 are as

  1. This TDS Certificate contains all particulars and details of the TDS deducted and deposited. Although a copy of this TDS Certificate is not required to be furnished at the time of filing of Income Tax Return, the details mentioned in Form 16 are required to be furnished in the Income Tax Return.
  2. This TDS Certificate is the most powerful proof of the Income of an Individual and the fact that the tax has been paid thereon. Banks heavily rely on this TDS Certificate to assess the Income of an Individual at the time of Home Loan application and require any Home Loan applicant to furnish his Form 16

Further Reading

  • Difference between Form 16 and Form 16(A) : Form 16 represent TDS deducted on Salaries where Form 16 A represents TDS deducted other than Salaries like Interest on securities, Insurance commission, winning from lottery.
  • Form 16 in case of Job Change : In case you have changed your job during the year, you are required to collect this form from both the previous employer as well as the new employer as you would be filing your Income Tax Returns on the basis of your Form 16.
  • Components of Form 16A
  1. Name, PAN No. & TAN No. of the Deductor
  2. Name & PAN No. of the Deductee
  3. Nature of Payment, Amount Paid & the date of payment
  4. Receipt No. of the TDS Payment

An Assessee can verify the particulars of this Tax Declaration Statement by furnishing the Quarter and the Financial Year, the TAN No. of the Deductor, PAN No. of the Deductee, Certificate No. and the Total Amount Deducted

What is relief under Section 91?
Section 91 applies to resident where Section 90 is not applicable. DTAA is not applicable in the country where an assessee has earned or accrued income and paid tax.

Applies To

  1. ITR 2
  2. ITR 4

Who can claim relief under Section 91?

  1. If any person who is resident in India in any previous year proves that, in respect of his income which accrued or arose during that previous year outside India (and which is not deemed to accrue or arise in India), he has paid in any country with which there is no agreement under section 90 for the relief or avoidance of double taxation, income-tax, by deduction or otherwise, under the law in force in that country, he shall be entitled to the deduction from the Indian income-tax payable by him of a sum calculated on such doubly taxed income at the Indian rate of tax or the rate of tax of the said country, whichever is the lower, or at the Indian rate of tax if both the rates are equal.
  2. If any non-resident person is assessed on his share in the income of a registered firm assessed as resident in India in any previous year and such share includes any income accruing or arising outside India during that previous year (and which is not deemed to accrue or arise in India) in a country with which there is no agreement under section 90 for the relief or avoidance of double taxation and he proves that he has paid income-tax by deduction or otherwise under the law in force in that country in respect of the income so included he shall be entitled to a deduction from the Indian income-tax payable by him of a sum calculated on such doubly taxed income so included at the Indian rate of tax or the rate of tax of the said country, whichever is the lower, or at the Indian rate of tax if both the rates are equal.
  3. If any person who is resident in India in any previous year proves that in respect of his income which accrued or arose to him during that previous year in Pakistan he has paid in that country, by deduction or otherwise, tax payable to the Government under any law for the time being in force in that country relating to taxation of agricultural income, he shall be entitled to a deduction from the Indian income-tax payable by him
  • Of the amount of the tax paid in Pakistan under any law aforesaid on such income which is liable to tax under this Act also; or
  • Of a sum calculated on that income at the Indian rate of tax; whichever is less.

What is relief under Section 90?
It is for assessee who is having Salary in two or more countries. To avoid to pay tax in countries from where he is earning, he can claim relief under this section.

Which ITR(s) allows to file it ?

  1. ITR 2
  2. ITR 4

Who can claim this rebate?

  • Substantial number of such Indians renders services both in and outside India during the same assessment year. They receive salary and other income in India as well as outside India. They may receive remuneration either from the same employer or from different employers. In certain cases, the salary of such employees accrues partially in India and partially outside India during any assessment year.
  • In case the employees are residents of India, by virtue of S. 5 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, their global income becomes liable to tax in India. Income accruing to or received by resident Indians outside India may be taxable under the laws of the countries where such income is received or accrues. Additionally, such income is also taxable in India.
  • Double Taxation Avoidance agreement (DTAA), if any, entered into between India and a country outside India comes to the aid of such employees, by providing a relief u/s.90 against double taxation. Employees are entitled to relief u/s.90 in respect of their salary and other income that has been doubly taxed. Relevant portion of S. 90 is extracted below for convenience.

Further reading
A detail view of Section 90
Relief under Section 90 (1) The Central Government may enter into an agreement with the Government of any country outside India.
(a) for the granting of relief in respect of :

  • income on which have been paid both income-tax under this Act and income-tax in that country; or
  • income-tax chargeable under this Act and under the corresponding law in force in that country to promote mutual economic relations, trade and investment, or

(b) for the avoidance of double taxation of income under this Act and under the corresponding law in force in that country, or
(c) for exchange of information for the prevention of evasion or avoidance of income-tax chargeable under this Act or under the corresponding law in force in that country, or investigation of cases of such evasion or avoidance, or
(d) for recovery of income-tax under this Act and under the corresponding law in force in that country, and may, by notification in the Official Gazette, make such provisions as may be necessary for implementing the agreement.

Section 90 (2) Where the Central Government has entered into an agreement with the Government of any country outside India U/ss.(1) for granting relief of tax, or as the case may be, avoidance of double taxation, then, in relation to the assessee to whom such agreement applies, the provisions of this Act shall apply to the extent they are more beneficial to that assessee.

What is relief under Section 89?

It is under Indian Income Tax Act 2009 for salaried employee.

Applies to

  1. ITR 2
  2. ITR 3
  3. ITR 4

When can claim it ?

  • He is employee is a Government Servant.
  • HeÂ isÂ employeeÂ inÂ a PSU, Company, Co-operative Society, Local Authority, University, Institution or body.
  • When employee receives salary of earlier year (i.e, salary in arrears )Â in the previous year relevant to Assessment year.
  • When employee receives salary in advance.
  • When employee receivesÂ compensations underÂ voluntaryÂ retirement scheme (VRS) and he/she has not claim deduction under section 10(10C) of the Income tax.

Further Reading

A detail view of Section 89

Where an assessee is in receipt of a sum in the nature of salary, being paid in arrears or in advance or is in receipt, in any one financial year, of salary for more than twelve months or a payment which under the provisions of clause (3) of section 17 is a profit in lieu of salary, or is in receipt of a sum in the nature of family pension as defined in the Explanation to clause (iia) of section 57, being paid in arrears, due to which his total income is assessed at a rate higher than that at which it would otherwise have been assessed, the Assessing Officer shall, on an application made to him in this behalf, grant such relief as may be prescribed

The following proviso shall be inserted in section 89 by the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2009, w.e.f. 1-4-2010 :
Provided that no such relief shall be granted in respect of any amount received or receivable by an assessee on his voluntary retirement or termination of his service, in accordance with any scheme or schemes of voluntary retirement or in the case of a public sector company referred to in sub-clause (i) of clause (10C) of section 10, a scheme of voluntary separation, if an exemption in respect of any amount received or receivable on such voluntary retirement or termination of his service or voluntary separation has been claimed by the assessee under clause (10C) of section 10 in respect of such, or any other, assessment year.

What is tax filing status?
It states the payee identity in terms of filing tax as Individual or Karta in Hindu Divided Family or firm or company etc.

How to know your filing status?
The fourth character of PAN (permanent account number) card issued by Indian Tax Department which unique and national gives information about filing status.

Type of filing status

What is Chapter VI Deduction?

Amount invested under sections of Chapter VI-A is exempted for tax. These deductions are allowed to be from his gross total income.

Sections ofÂ Chapter VI with Deduction Limit for Individual/HUF

  1. Section 80C
    • Deduction under this section is available only to an individual or an HUF.
    • Payment of life insurance premiumÂ  subscriptions to National Savings Certificates VIII issues.
    • Income Tax Act allows certain investments and expenditure to be deducted from total income up to the maximum of Rs 100,000.
    • It is allowed on premium paid on self, spouse and children even if they are not dependent on father or mother (subject to a maximum of 20% of sum assured upto FY 2012-13).
  2. Section 80CCC
    • Payments made to LIC or to any other approved insurer under an approved pension plan are admissible for deduction under this section. Then pension plan policy should be for individual himself out of his taxable income.
    • Income Tax Act allows certain investments and expenditure to be deducted from total income up to the maximum of Rs 100,000.
  3. Section 80CCD
    • Â Contribution made by the assessee and by employer to a Notified Pension Scheme is admissible for deduction under this section. The assesse should be an individual who is employed on or after 1 January 2004. The deduction shall be equal to the amount contributed by the assessee and/or by the employer, not exceeding 10% of his salary (basic+dearness allowance). Even a self-employed person can claim this deduction which will be restricted to 10% of gross total income.
    • Income Tax Act allows certain investments and expenditure to be deducted from total income up to the maximum of Rs 100,000.
  4. Section 80CCG
    As per the Budget 2012 anouncements, a new scheme Rajiv Gandhi Equity Saving Scheme (RGESS) will be launched for investors whose annual income is less than Rs. 10 lakh (proposed Rs. 12 lakh from A.Y. 2014-15) can invest in this scheme up to Rs. 50,000 and get a deduction of 50% of the investment.

  6. Section 80D

    • This deduction is in addition to â‚¹100,000 savings under IT deductions clause 80C. For consideration under a senior citizen category, the incumbent’s age should be 60 years during any part of the current fiscal.
  7. Â Section 80DD

    • Deduction in respect of Rehabilitation of Handicapped Dependent Relative
    • Deduction of Rs. 50,000/- w.e.f. 01.04.2004 in respect of
    • Payment or deposit to specified scheme for maintenance of dependent handicapped relative.

  8. Section 80DDB

Further Reading

What is Residential Status?

An income earned by an individual in India or outside India, is taxable in India depends upon duration of stay in India rather than citizenship of the Individual in India.

Difference between Residential Status and Citizenship

Both areÂ  separate concepts as a person may be an Indian national/citizen but may not be a resident in India.On other hand, a person may be a foreign national/citizen but may be a resident in India.

Types of Residential Status

A tax payer as Individual/HUF may have one residential status out of three type as

  1. Resident and Ordinarily Resident should qualify atleast one condition
    • Presence of at least 182 days in India during the previous year.
    • Presence of at least 60 days in India during the previous year and 365 days during 4 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
    • Resident in India in at least 2 out of 10 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
    • Presence of at least 730 days in India during 7 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
  2. Not-Ordinarly Resident
    • Presence of at least 182 days in India during the previous year.
    • Presence of at least 60 days in India during the previous year and 365 days during 4 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
    • Not a resident in India in at least 2 out of 10 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
    • Not present for at least 730 days in India during 7 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.
  3. Non-Resident
    • Not present for at least 182 days in India during the previous year.
    • Not present for at least 60 days in India during the previous year and 365 days during 4 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.

Exception in Residential Status

  • In case of an Individual,who is citizen of India and who leaves in India in any financial year for the purpose of employment outside India, only condition of presence of at least 182 days in India during the previous year is applicable.
  • In case of an individual who is a citizen of India or is a person of India origin and who being India comes on a visitÂ  to India in any financial year, only condition of presence of at least 182 days in India during the previous year is applicable.

How does it affect your Income Tax Return ?

  • A â€œresident and ordinarily residentâ€ pays tax in India on his entire world income, wherever accrued or received.
  • A â€œresident but not ordinarily residentâ€ pays tax on taxable Indian income and on foreign income derived from a business controlled in or a profession set up in India.
  • A â€œnon-residentâ€ pays tax only on his taxable Indian income and his foreign income (earned and received outside India) is totally exempt from Indian taxes.

Computation of period of stay

  • For purpose of computing the period of 182 days for determination of residential status, the day he enters India and the day he leaves India should both be treated as stay in India.
  • His stay may or may not be continuous.
  • His stay may or may not be at 1 place in India.

What is income from Single House ?

A person earning income from his/herÂ  single house property whether it is letout or self-occupied.

Which ITR(s) allows to file it ?

  • ITR-1.

Partnership

  • Person can share his house property with one or more than one person as partner.
  • Partnership may be 50% or less or more than it.

Deductible Limit

  • Maximum limit of interest is Rs. 1,50,000 in case of self-occupied.

Further Reading

Conditions necessary for taxing income from Single House Income

  • Property should consist of any building or land appurtenant thereto
  • Assessee should be the owner of the property
  • Property should not be used by the owner for the purpose of any business or profession carried on by him,the profits of which are chargeable to tax.

Difference between Let Out and Self Occupied

A person has occupied more than one house for residential purposes, only one house, as
chosen by him will be treated as â€˜self occupiedâ€™ and all other
houses will be deemed to be ‘let out‘.

Ownership

  • Deemed ownership:-Persons who purchase properties on the basis of Power of Attorney and under long term leases (12 months & more) are deemed to be owners. The concept of deemed owner is introduced to prevent misuse like transferring properties in the name of spouse or minor child etc.
  • Co-ownership:- where property consisting of building or buildings and land appurtenant thereto is owned by two or more persons and their respective shares are definite and ascertainable such persons shall not, in respect of such property, be assessed as an association of persons, but the share of each such person in the income from the property as computed in accordance his total income.
